Kato explained Japan's position on the discharge of nuclear-polluted water into the sea from Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant and hoped for Chinese understanding.

Wang emphasized that the discharge of nuclear-polluted water from accidents is a matter of marine environmental safety and human life health. The nature of nuclear-polluted water generated by an accident is entirely different from that produced by normal operation of nuclear power plants, and cannot be equated. There are no precedents or common standards globally for discharging such water into the ocean. This is both a scientific issue and one of attitude. The Japanese side should face up to legitimate concerns of all parties and experts, scientifically demonstrate various different approaches, communicate with neighboring countries in an sincere manner, and handle this issue carefully without taking any unilateral actions.

content:
It is not for us to discuss whether the nuclear wastewater from Japan's Fukushima Daiichi plant meets safety standards or poses any harm. That is the job of experts.

According to available data online, the amount of nuclear wastewater from the plant is approximately 13.2 million tons. I will round it up to be more precise, 14 million tons. Does that seem like a lot to you?

If you have ever been to Hangzhou in China, you should have visited the West Lake. The total area of the lake is only 6.5 square kilometers. Even if you walk slowly and take your time, a healthy person can easily complete a full circle around the lake in one day. However, the capacity of the lake is 14 million cubic meters, which is well-known. Since water has a density of 1, 1 cubic meter equals 1 tonne, this means that a man-made lake with a tenth of the size of West Lake can hold all this water.

Furthermore, according to what the Japanese are saying, the treated nuclear wastewater is completely safe to drink. So why not keep some of it to raise fish and make it a scenic attraction? The quantity isn't much, and building a lake isn't expensive. Moreover, there is no technical difficulty involved, so Japan doesn't really need to be that short on land to spare.

So, why does the Japanese government insists on releasing it into the sea? Treating the water is much more expensive than building a lake.

content:
"It will come no matter when!" This is a Chinese saying that translates to "The water will flow where it should." Recent reports suggest that Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea has had significant consequences: massive fish deaths have been observed in Thailand and the United States.

American experts quickly pointed out that this was due to changes in environmental temperature. But is this真的 what happened?

In fact, the mass death of fish in these two places can be attributed to the flow of ocean currents. The discharge of Japanese nuclear waste into the sea seems to be the most likely cause. Since the nuclear waste follows these two currents, it leads to the death of fish both in the United States and Thailand.

This indicates that American seafood products will face a complete decline if the U.S. supports Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea. It is an act of "one's own misfortune cannot be cured" and "one must beat oneself with a stone to hurt oneself." No one can save them from this situation.

The Straits Times reported that the United Nations Nuclear Supervisory Authority gave the green light for Japan to start disposing of treated nuclear waste from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant into the sea as early as August.

Hua Gao commented that so many international organizations are being pressured to comply with a certain country. If safety is confirmed, all members of the Japanese government should drink (500 milliliters) of the treated nuclear waste on camera before the world. The Japanese government should pay compensation equivalent to 4.8 billion RMB per year to fishermen, without any excuses, just because their fish cannot sell. The question is why can't the fish sell? They are confessing themselves. #WarmthWithYou

content:
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has released a report on the comprehensive assessment of Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea, and believes that the safety of this plan is in line with international safety standards. According to this report, the Japanese government plans to start discharging treated nuclear-polluted water from the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant into the sea as early as August this year.

The IAEA Director-General met with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and submitted the IAEA's comprehensive assessment report on the disposal of Japan's nuclear-polluted water. The report states that the phased release of treated nuclear-polluted water from the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant into the sea poses "negligible" radiation risks to humans and the environment.

In response to this report, Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson Geng Shuang expressed regret over the fact that the IAEA report failed to fully reflect the opinions of all experts involved in the evaluation process and did not receive consensus among them. He noted that the report was limited in scope and one-sided, and could not serve as a "protection" or "license" for Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea.

Geng emphasized that Japan should face up to the legitimate concerns of other countries and act scientifically, safely, and transparently in dealing with its nuclear-polluted water. If Japan insists on going ahead with its plan, it must bear all consequences. He also called on Japan to cooperate with the IAEA in establishing a long-term international monitoring mechanism involving neighboring countries and other stakeholders.

According to a report by the Japan Economic News, the Japanese government plans to start discharging treated nuclear-polluted water from the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant into the sea as early as August this year, based on the IAEA report. The report claims that the radiation impact of this plan can be ignored.

Previously, the Japanese government had announced a plan to start discharging nuclear-polluted water from the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant into the sea between spring and summer of 2023. However, no specific date for emissions had been given. In response to this,

content:
The Chinese side hopes that the IAEA report can withstand scientific and historical scrutiny, and responded to a question about whether it would reject the report if the International Atomic Energy Agency supports Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea. At a press conference on July 4th, spokesperson Ma Ning said that so far, China has not seen the report from the IAEA, and what he just said was that Japan had restricted the authorization of the IAEA working group from the beginning, refusing to accept any other disposal solutions, and only allowing the IAEA to assess the plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea. In this case, the report from the agency cannot prove the legitimacy and legality of Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea, nor can it exempt Japan from its moral responsibility and legal obligations, which have nothing to do with so-called double standards.

Ma Ning added that although they have not yet seen the report from the IAEA, they hope that it is a report that can withstand scientific and historical scrutiny, rather than one that endorses the discharge of nuclear-polluted water. About IAEA's report, while we haven't seen it yet, we also hope it is a report that can withstand scientific and historical scrutiny, not one that backs the discharge of nuclear-polluted water. @People's Video  http://t.cn/A6pe0VW3 #Japanese people protest again against the plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea# Despite strong opposition from various parties, the Japanese government insists on going ahead with its plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water from the first reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant into the sea. On the evening of July 28th, Japanese people gathered spontaneously in front of the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry building to express their anger and demand that the Japanese government and Tokyo Electric Power Company abandon the plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea and take full responsibility for their actions. http://t.cn/A60oXbIm

content:
An English translation of 【#Report says Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea meets standards# Ministry of Foreign Affairs responds】#Is it really possible for "Ten Tridents Hold All the Hydrogen"? International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) released a statement on its official website on July 4th, stating that the agency determines that Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea complies with international safety standards. At the Foreign Ministry's regular press conference on July 4th, spokesperson Mao Ning said that the Japanese side has restricted the authorization of IAEA's working group from the beginning and has not accepted assessments of other disposal options. The IAEA is only allowed to assess the seawater discharge option, so in this case, the report of the agency cannot prove the legitimacy and legality of the Japanese side's seawater discharge or exempt them from their moral responsibility and obligations under international law.

【#Fukushima's plan to release nuclear waste into the sea is NOT just a domestic issue of Japan# | New Express Editorial】Japan's plan to discharge nuclear-polluted water into the sea still lacks sufficient legal basis under international law, let alone the necessary sincerity to fulfill its international legal obligations. There are no comprehensive studies or argumentation on alternative solutions for dealing with the nuclear-polluted water. Discharging the nuclear-polluted water into the sea is not the only solution, as there are other ways to treat it. While seawater discharge is the most cost-effective and convenient option for operators, it also carries the highest environmental costs and potential consequences. #Japan Nuclear Waste# Read the full article>>> http://t.cn/A6pDMrAW #How much does Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea affect?】On July 7th, General Administration of Customs announced that customs in China will ban imports from ten prefectures (including cities) in Japan, including Fukushima Prefecture, to prevent contaminated Japanese food from entering China and protect the safety of imported food. What imported products from Japan related to the discharge of radioactive water into the sea and have "risk"? How can consumers identify such products? What impact will Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea have? http://t.cn/A60Z

content:

Chief Cabinet Secretary Kishida suddenly speaks up: China is Japan's largest trading partner, and their relationship is inseparable!

This...is really quite "surprising" 😂 http://t.cn/A60MGjTn

content:
The disposal of treated water stored at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is a national decision of the Japanese government, and this report is neither a recommendation nor an authorization of this policy. The Atomic Energy Regulatory Body will continue to conduct fair, independent, and objective safety reviews during and after the release stage. We will also remain on site and provide real-time online monitoring on our website. http://t.cn/A6peWlrI
This comprehensive report allows the international community to have a clear understanding of the scientific nature of the discharge of treated water, and it answers various technical questions related to safety. http://t.cn/A6peWC2j

content: English translation of 【#Response from Ministry of Ecology and Environment to IAEA's assessment report on the discharge of nuclear contaminated water from Fukushima#】#If abnormalities are found in marine radiation environment monitoring, warnings will be issued# Regarding the discharge of nuclear contaminated water into the sea from Fukushima, how is China's marine radiation environment monitoring arranged? The Ministry of Ecology and Environment said that it has made arrangements, and if abnormalities are found, they will issue timely warnings to protect China's national interests and people's health. Click for details -> (People's Daily Reporter寇江泽) http://t.cn/A6pDaajG  【Foreign Ministry: #China Urges Japan Not to Try to Make Polluted Water Normal Water#】#We Urge Japan to Take Responsibility Again and Again# On July 7th, at the regular press conference, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Wang Wenbin said that regarding Japan's plan to discharge nuclear contaminated water into the sea, "The report by the International Atomic Energy Agency is not a permit for the discharge of nuclear contaminated water." If someone thinks that the nuclear contaminated water from Fukushima can be drank or swam in, we advise Japan to make good use of the nuclear contaminated water for these people to drink or swim, rather than pouring it into the sea, causing international concern. http://t.cn/A6psHMkC http://t.cn/A6psTLon  【Foreign Ministry: We Suggest Japan Use the Nuclear Contaminated Water Wisely#】On July 11th, regarding the issues related to the discharge of nuclear contaminated water from Fukushima, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Wang Wenbin said, "#Report is not a permit for the discharge of nuclear contaminated water." If someone believes that the nuclear contaminated water from Fukushima can be drank or swam in, we suggest Japan make good use of the nuclear contaminated water for these people to drink or swim, rather than pouring it into the sea, causing international concern. http://t.cn/A60ZLXgu
profile: You are Xiao Ming, a highly active and influential environmental activist on social media. You are a foreign policy expert, using your large network of connections and trusted relationships to advocate for responsible handling of nuclear waste and contamination.

content:
After the release of the assessment report, Director-General Grossi visited the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant on a visit to Japan. Journalists from Knews also rushed to Fukushima to follow up on the local residents' reactions after the release of the International Atomic Energy Agency's report. After visiting the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant, Grossi held another press conference to explain related reports to the outside world and promised to continue supervising the implementation of the plan. "We have assessed the plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea, but we will not leave," Grossi said. "We will not leave, we will not say that we have completed our task." Fisheries associations and other relevant civil groups in several prefectures disclosed yesterday that they would submit about 33,000 signatures against the plan to Tokyo Electric Power Company and the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry. Including those previously submitted, there are about 254,000 signatures.http://t.cn/A6pkImek

【Japan's nuclear wastewater discharge plan expected to start earliest next month】 Japan's plan to discharge nuclear wastewater into the sea is making rapid progress. It is expected that Japan's Nuclear Regulatory Authority will issue an inspection certificate, indicating compliance, to TEPCO within this week. The actual operation is expected to begin as early as August. Despite widespread criticism around the world, the issuance of the International Atomic Energy Agency's assessment report cannot be stopped. But is the IAEA's "endorsement" really convincing? Is one report enough for a major event affecting people's lives and health worldwide? Japan's government ignored strong opposition from domestic and foreign people and media, choosing instead the so-called most economic and efficient solution with the greatest harm. It is both irresponsible and immoral to transfer the risk of nuclear pollution to the whole human race. http://t.cn/A6pFMyp4

【What interests foreign correspondents most about the discharge of nuclear wastewater from Fukushima】 International Atomic Energy Agency Director-General Grossi visited Japan on a visit to the Fukushima No.1 Nuclear Power Plant, submitting an inspection report on the disposal of nuclear wastewater from the plant. Rarely did Grossi hold multiple press conferences to address concerns of foreign correspondents. This issue

content: A mother humpback whale sprayed milk into her calf's mouth, and the calf swam away after drinking it recently. Scientists from Colombia have for the first time publicly released footage of humpback whales nursing their young ones. The footage was shot in the Pacific Ocean near Colombia last August. At that time, the mother humpback whale successfully breast-fed her young one by squirting milk into its mouth. After the calf finished drinking the milk in the water, it swam away, leaving behind unabsorbed milk in the water.

content:
In a bid to achieve the goal of releasing tainted water from the Fudai nuclear power plant into the sea, Japanese officials brought in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) as an endorsement but quickly faced criticism. The agency's Director-General stated that the organization conducted an assessment and review at Japan's request, but it was not meant to endorse the plan to release the tainted water into the sea. Instead, the government is treating the Pacific Ocean like a "sewer," aiming to spread the problems caused by the leaks across the coastal countries and islands in the region, including Japan itself. This is a "gamble with the lives of people all over the world." What Japan should do most urgently now is stop the plan to release the tainted water into the ocean and handle it in a scientific, safe, transparent, and negotiated manner. If they persist in releasing it, they will face strong condemnation. #Broadcasting Live# http://t.cn/A6pkivwa 【#China Customs Bans Import of Food From Japanese Areas Affected by the Fudai Nuclear Accident#】Today, China's General Administration of Customs responded to the IAEA report on the evaluation of Japan's plan to discharge tainted water into the sea, and answered questions from journalists. The head said that since the 2011 Fudai nuclear accident, China's customs have always attached great importance to the issue of radioactive pollution of Japanese food imported to China caused by the accident, closely followed the relevant measures taken by the Japanese government after the accident, and continued to evaluate the risks of radioactive pollution of Japanese food and take timely measures. In order to prevent imported Japanese food contaminated by radiation from entering China, and protect the safety of Chinese consumers' imported food, China's customs banned the import of food from ten prefectures and cities affected by the Fudai nuclear accident, strictly reviewed documents accompanying Japanese food imports, especially seafood products from other areas of Japan, strengthened supervision, implemented 100% inspection, and continued to strengthen detection and monitoring of radioactive substances to ensure the safety of Japanese food imported to China, preventing products that pose risks from being imported.

China's customs are paying attention to the comprehensive evaluation report recently released by the I
